Blazblue Entropy Effect is a game that really surprised me, as a Blazblue fan originally I was a bit upset to read about how little the game has to do with Blazblue itself and wrote it off as a cash grab; but after grabbing it on sale I can say that this is a great game with a coat of Blazblue paint, and the recently announced Entropy Effect X seems to be going deep into actually connecting the game to the wider Blazblue universe, though they're yet to announce what this means for us PC players; hopefully a paid expansion for us and not a whole new game to purchase.

Entropy Effect is not a Blazblue game ostensibly but it is a fun roguelite action game featuring Blazblue characters, who have all been pretty loving adapted for this game. They look great, feel great to play, and have familiar moves you'll recognize from the home fighting games and it all works well; the result is a sort of fighting game hack and slash hybrid that has tons of build variety and replay value.

There is a story here but it's really unremarkable and doesn't really seem to have anything to do with Blazblue though Entropy Effect X seems to be changing this, hopefully the devs don't do us dirty seeing the price for the console version; with any luck they'll release the expansion for us as a paid DLC. 

If you like Blazblue, there's enough care put into these adaptations of the characters that you'll probably like this game and how it retains the fighting game feel despite the genre shift. If you like roguelikes or side scrolling action games, you can do far worse than this one, especially with it regularly going on sale for great prices. Looking forward to learning what comes next in Entropy Effect X.

Speaking as both a fighting game player and a combat platformer fan, BBEE is the best combat platformer there is in the market right now. While the connection with Blazblue is strenuous (the story of this game, which is pretty simple, has nothing to do with BB. The characters are just "avatars" and can be anyone) you can feel the developers' love for fighting games baked into every element of it. 

This is the sort of game that doesn't have a lot of "content" but has pretty high replayability. Don't expect to progress like you would in a more linear roguelike. It's more the sort you pick up and play and have fun with for an hour every once in a while.

Have you ever seen a stick fight animation and wanted to play a game like that? Have you been moderately dissapointed that while YOMI hustle is almost that, and a good game in it's own right, the turn based mechanics really diminish the value you see in flashy combat that you wish you could properly be a part of?

This, my friend, is the game for you. It's a roguelike with balancing inspired by Hades and combat based around the fighting games ArcSys is known for, alongside their signature incomprehensible storylines. I have played this for less than a day of work, and I've already advanced to becoming something close to a god several times and have only been stopped by my single grievance of lacking the ability to loop or otherwise continue a run indefinitely.

I don't even know what buttons I'm pressing half the time but the game tries it's hardest to make you feel like an evo champion. It's a power fantasy to the maximum and absolutely worth the $20 USD.

I love this game. The art style is immaculate, the performance is solid, the music is nice. But most importantly, the gameplay loop is just so fun. Not one character plays the same, you'll find someone to have fun obliterating enemies with no matter who it is.

This game also gets a lot of support, including free characters/content and paid DLC that, while not entirely unreasonably priced, does go on sale regularly. 

The major shortcomings (Apart from the lack of stage variety) are the story and the online, generally. The story has nothing to do with the main BlazBlue games, and is serviceable but nothing particularly special. And although I haven't had a particularly bad time myself, the multiplayer servers are known to struggle often, and so if you want to play with friends, it's important to keep that in mind.

Entropy Effect X, the sequel/expansion has just been announced, and so all the negatives could just go away at that point from what we've seen. But it's too early to say for sure.

I saw the trailer for this game last night and was immediately sold. The style, the energy, the Dead Cells Prisoner cameo‚Äîit all looked like the perfect blend of things I love. On paper, it really seemed like a dream game.

Actually playing it was a different story. The game is built around these short stages where you fight through a handful of enemies or a boss, collect points, and spend them on upgrades. There are multiple characters, which is great in theory, but the structure left me cold. The trailers and description gave me the impression this would play more like Dead Cells or The Rogue Prince of Persia, with larger, flowing biomes you can sink into. Instead, it‚Äôs all broken up into little chunks. That constant interruption makes the runs feel stop-and-go, and for me, it sucked the fun out of what could have been a fantastic loop. At times it honestly feels like a very polished mobile game blown up for PC, rather than something built around long, immersive sessions.

It‚Äôs frustrating because the combat itself feels really good. The animations are sharp, the abilities are flashy, and chaining attacks together is satisfying. I wanted to love it. But with the pacing chopped up into quick encounters, I never got that same sense of immersion or progression I was expecting.

On top of that, the DLC pricing doesn‚Äôt help. Charging nearly half the cost of the base game for a single extra character feels off, especially when character variety is supposed to be a core feature. It left a bad taste and made me less inclined to keep investing time into it.

I ended up refunding the game. It‚Äôs not terrible by any means, and I can see the appeal if you‚Äôre into short, snappy stages, but it just wasn‚Äôt what I was led to believe from the previews. Maybe I‚Äôll give it another shot someday if it goes on a deep sale, but for now, it‚Äôs not for me.

You pick a core character, you unlock more and more of their moveset as you progress through Potentials, and all the "Tactics" you get along the way are basically just riders that tack on some bonus effects to those moves. I didn't expect much from a roguelike/roguelight game type but it's a positive surprise.

You get what you most likely expect from this genre:
Great controls, well designed characters (with some humor too), randomization, more randomization but not necessarily a good story or level design. Boss fights gained a higher focus and they are overall well done. I usually don't like randomized levels because they tend to be of lower quality in solo gameplay but it's okay in multiplayer. The true boon of BlazBlue Entropy Effect is playing together with someone else. This co-op style can be very enjoyable, funny and sometimes frustrating too. That's entertaining and lastly what matters. Additionally, the game has beautiful graphics but that's also a downside. The graphic design and system requirements are like a high tech temple built for a game style taken from a SNES console game. That's not exactly a complaint but a SSD shouldn't make a difference for these type of games. Most players will be happy with less fancy elements and graphically enhanced rooms/spots are used for a duplicate effect: To call a list from the option menu.

It should be pointed out that players have to face a lot of grinding, rinse and repeat with the target to complete a scene or bosss fight perfectly, just to repeat the procedure over and over again. Variety comes from playable characters, so called evotypes and the possibility to obtain certain benefits. The character can inherit abilities from up to 2 other characters and use up to 2 of their prior collected "tactics". Tactics are additional effects and damage effects that execute on regular attacks, skills used and so on. These tactics can be collected but it's not possible to assign them freely. It's an unfortunate decision in my eyes. Characters have their own unique set of abilities that can be upgraded over the process playing solo or in multiplayer, each.

All in all, there is a bit too much randomness within the game that takes away too much control of players and how they want to play. However, the multiplayer option, a good selection of characters and additional DLC content with more characters compensate for it.

A major downside and weakness is communication. The game is terrible at explaining how things work and players are limited to a few messages to express what they want and how they want to play. It doesn't give the basic needs like "Give me 1 minute, then we can play.", "Let's use settings ABC, not XYZ, please." and son on. Nobody needs "Let's jump, now!". There's no way of telling someone, "Oh, hey! That tactic A is great and it can unlock an awesome effect with your currently existing tactic B.".
